BIOS205
Notes
New module as part of programme revalidation. Due to commence September 2024, starting with year 1.

Overview

Overview
This 15-credit module will continue to develop students' communication and writing skills. In addition students will develop research, problem-solving and employability skills. This module will be built around fortnightly small-group tutorials with Academic Advisors with a weekly lecture to introduce the different themes. Students will complete four assessments which include an essay, a written critique of lay science communication, an individual report and group digital pitch, and a portfolio. As this module is taken by students on all programmes, to allow students to explore their interests different essay titles, journal papers and discussion topics relevant to students programme area of interest will be offered.
Educational Aims
This module aims to:

● To further develop students’ problem solving and critical thinking skills;

● To further develop students’ ability to reflect on their progress and use feedback to identify opportunities for personal development;

● To further develop students' employability, career thinking and engagement with industry;

● To further develop students written and communication skills;

● To help students continue to develop a professional relationship with peers and academics.
Marketing Module Synopsis
This module will continue to develop students’ transferable skills and will build on the year 1 skills module. It will focus on improving the students’ written, communication, and employability skills. As this module is taken by students on all programmes, to allow students to explore their interests different essay titles, journal papers and discussion topics relevant to students programme area of interest will be offered. Students will complete four assessments which include an essay, a written critique of lay science communication, an individual report and group digital pitch, and a portfolio. The module is based on fortnightly small-group tutorials with an Academic Advisor. Each tutorial will have a topic that relates to a small task which students need to complete either before or after the tutorial. The topics will be introduced within plenary lectures. In addition to the plenary lectures relating to skills development and employability, students will also receive lectures and seminars relating to programme specific content. These lectures will form the basis for discussions in programme specific tutorials
Outline Syllabus
Lecture and tutorial themes:

Publishing and citing research
● The peer review process
● Primary research articles

Communicating with different audiences
● Principles and forms of communication
● Effective communication
● Audiences
● Relevance for science/ employability

Giving presentations and digital pitches
● Designing and delivering a presentation or digital pitch
● Presentation tools

Critical thinking
● Why is critical thinking important?

Self-reflection
● Why is self-reflection important?
● Relevance to employability

Teamwork
● Why work in teams?
● How to be a successful team member
● Inclusive working and valuing perspectives

Employability
● Developing your CV
● Developing video interview skills
● How to target your application

Sustainability
● Responsible and sustainable innovation in Biosciences

Research Ethics
● Ethics of experimentation on animals and humans
● University's ethical policies and procedures
● Ethical approval process


These underpinning and additional skills will be recorded and assessed within the reflective portfolio. Submission of summative assessments will be through Canvas. Students will be expected to maintain their portfolio, prepare for small group tutorials and to carry out independent research to develop the content of their summative assessments.
Teaching and Learning Methods
The module is based on fortnightly small-group tutorials with an Academic Advisor. Each tutorial will have a topic that relates to a small task which students need to complete either before or after the tutorial. The topics will be introduced within plenary lectures. In addition to the plenary lectures relating to skills development and employability, students will also receive lectures and seminars relating to programme specific content. These lectures will form the basis for discussions in programme specific tutorials. Tutorial topics will include e.g. research skills, writing skills, and career development. In the tutorial, anonymous examples of appropriate and inappropriate resources will be evaluated and discussed. The portfolio will contain a number of small tasks which include a skills audit, reflection on module tasks such as cv and video interviews and opportunity to reflect on academic feedback and the development of skills. The tasks will be marked using simple rubrics. In addition to the portfolio there are three marked written assessments, one in Semester 1 and two in Semester 2.

Teaching method 1 – Lectures
Lectures will introduce the topic and skills which will be developed in each of the study cycles. Lectures will be related to the theme/ topic areas outlined in the Outline Syllabus section.
Attendance recorded: Yes

Teaching method 2 – Seminars
Seminars will supplement the material provided in the lectures and have more of a programme specific content focus. These seminars will form the basis for discussions in the programme specific tutorials.
Attendance recorded: Yes

Teaching method 3 – Tutorials
Students will have fortnightly small group tutorials with an Academic Advisor. Each tutorial will have a topic that relates to a small task which students need to complete either before or after the tutorial
Attendance recorded: Yes

The nature and implementation of this method is specifically designed to incorporate the hallmarks of the Liverpool Curriculum Framework, in the following ways: 

Research-connected teaching: As part of the module students will have programme specific content designed and delivered by research-active/ connected scientists to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research and best evidence. Assessment submissions from learners should be evidence-based by their exploration of primary literature, and suitably referenced.  

Inclusivity and accessibility: Resource templates use accessible fonts and colour schemes. Content is uploaded to the VLE in advance, in a format compatible with assistive technologies and checked proactively with Ally. Format adjustments are also available on request in accordance with specific learning disabilities and support plans. Lectures are recorded and available on the VLE. 

Active learning: Structured participation will be interactive, using quizzes (e.g. PollEverywhere, Mentimeter, Kahoot) and collaborative, interactive tools (e.g. Padlet, Miro). Students will work together in groups to address an authentic challenge as part of the module. Formative exercises will provide students with regular feedback on their learning. 

Authentic assessment: The teaching and learning in this module, and the assessment strategy will foster skills desirable in many sectors of employment and those of lifelong learning. There are four assessments. Students will learn to communicate to difference audiences a key skill for scientists. One assessment, an essay which will encourage students to search literature and think critically whilst there is a written science communication where students will need to communicate using lay, non-technical language. In another assessment, students will work in groups to identify a solution to an authentic problem facing the life sciences sector. This will require problem-solving, critical thinking, project planning etc. There is also a portfolio where students will reflect on their skills development and academic feedback.

Confidence: This is developed continuously throughout the module. Tutorials are discursive and interactive, with learners contributing ideas and analysis to ongoing discussion. This builds confidence by creating a ‘safe space’ for sharing of ideas and expertise.  

Digital fluency: Digital fluency is encouraged through a combination of methods. The VLE is used for formative and summative assessment. Assessment activity also requires students to develop competency with digital technology. As part of one assessment, students will develop a group digital pitch showcasing a solution to a problem facing the life sciences sector.

Global citizenship: Students will study areas from their programme of interest at a Global Scale. Examples may include organisms, their development, their varied physiology, and immunity, infection, and therapeutics at a global scale. Our curriculum embeds values of inclusivity, equality and sustainability. In learning materials, we prioritise representation of diverse imagery and use scientific cases which reflect issues affecting marginalised communities.  

In exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
There are four assessments :
Assessment 1 - 1000 word essay (25%)
Assessment 2 - Individual Written report (500 words) and Group Digital Pitch with marks distributed according to peer assessed contribution (30%)
Assesement 3 - 750 word critique of a piece of lay science communication which has been generated by generative artificial intelligence (GAI) (25%)
Assessment 4 - Portfolio consisting of number of small tasks. (20%) This will include a skills audit, reflection on module tasks such as a cv and video interview and opportunity to reflect on academic feedback and the development of skills.

The assessment strategy has been guided by the Liverpool Curriculum Framework attributes and hallmarks, particularly with respect to confidence, active learning, digital fluency, and authentic assessment. Individual and group feedback on authentic-assessments and self-reflections aim to support the development of study and employability skills, such as resilience and ability to recognise, and act upon, constructive feedback. A key component of the assessment is therefore the production of a skills/self-reflection portfolio. In addition to the portfolio, the three other assessments are designed to be authentic and will require students to combine all the skills they have developed over the course of the module.

Reassessment will use the same format but the topic or data will differ. Mark will be capped at 40%. This will take place in the normal reassessment window. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

Notes
New module as part of programme revalidation. Due to commence September 2024, starting with year 1.

Overview

Overview
This 15-credit module will continue to develop students' communication and writing skills. In addition students will develop research, problem-solving and employability skills. This module will be built around fortnightly small-group tutorials with Academic Advisors with a weekly lecture to introduce the different themes. Students will complete four assessments which include an essay, a written critique of lay science communication, an individual report and group digital pitch, and a portfolio. As this module is taken by students on all programmes, to allow students to explore their interests different essay titles, journal papers and discussion topics relevant to students programme area of interest will be offered.
Educational Aims
This module aims to:

● To further develop students’ problem solving and critical thinking skills;

● To further develop students’ ability to reflect on their progress and use feedback to identify opportunities for personal development;

● To further develop students' employability, career thinking and engagement with industry;

● To further develop students written and communication skills;

● To help students continue to develop a professional relationship with peers and academics.
Marketing Module Synopsis
This module will continue to develop students’ transferable skills and will build on the year 1 skills module. It will focus on improving the students’ written, communication, and employability skills. As this module is taken by students on all programmes, to allow students to explore their interests different essay titles, journal papers and discussion topics relevant to students programme area of interest will be offered. Students will complete four assessments which include an essay, a written critique of lay science communication, an individual report and group digital pitch, and a portfolio. The module is based on fortnightly small-group tutorials with an Academic Advisor. Each tutorial will have a topic that relates to a small task which students need to complete either before or after the tutorial. The topics will be introduced within plenary lectures. In addition to the plenary lectures relating to skills development and employability, students will also receive lectures and seminars relating to programme specific content. These lectures will form the basis for discussions in programme specific tutorials
Outline Syllabus
Lecture and tutorial themes:

Publishing and citing research
● The peer review process
● Primary research articles

Communicating with different audiences
● Principles and forms of communication
● Effective communication
● Audiences
● Relevance for science/ employability

Giving presentations and digital pitches
● Designing and delivering a presentation or digital pitch
● Presentation tools

Critical thinking
● Why is critical thinking important?

Self-reflection
● Why is self-reflection important?
● Relevance to employability

Teamwork
● Why work in teams?
● How to be a successful team member
● Inclusive working and valuing perspectives

Employability
● Developing your CV
● Developing video interview skills
● How to target your application

Sustainability
● Responsible and sustainable innovation in Biosciences

Research Ethics
● Ethics of experimentation on animals and humans
● University's ethical policies and procedures
● Ethical approval process


These underpinning and additional skills will be recorded and assessed within the reflective portfolio. Submission of summative assessments will be through Canvas. Students will be expected to maintain their portfolio, prepare for small group tutorials and to carry out independent research to develop the content of their summative assessments.
Teaching and Learning Methods
The module is based on fortnightly small-group tutorials with an Academic Advisor. Each tutorial will have a topic that relates to a small task which students need to complete either before or after the tutorial. The topics will be introduced within plenary lectures. In addition to the plenary lectures relating to skills development and employability, students will also receive lectures and seminars relating to programme specific content. These lectures will form the basis for discussions in programme specific tutorials. Tutorial topics will include e.g. research skills, writing skills, and career development. In the tutorial, anonymous examples of appropriate and inappropriate resources will be evaluated and discussed. The portfolio will contain a number of small tasks which include a skills audit, reflection on module tasks such as cv and video interviews and opportunity to reflect on academic feedback and the development of skills. The tasks will be marked using simple rubrics. In addition to the portfolio there are three marked written assessments, one in Semester 1 and two in Semester 2.

Teaching method 1 – Lectures
Lectures will introduce the topic and skills which will be developed in each of the study cycles. Lectures will be related to the theme/ topic areas outlined in the Outline Syllabus section.
Attendance recorded: Yes

Teaching method 2 – Seminars
Seminars will supplement the material provided in the lectures and have more of a programme specific content focus. These seminars will form the basis for discussions in the programme specific tutorials.
Attendance recorded: Yes

Teaching method 3 – Tutorials
Students will have fortnightly small group tutorials with an Academic Advisor. Each tutorial will have a topic that relates to a small task which students need to complete either before or after the tutorial
Attendance recorded: Yes

The nature and implementation of this method is specifically designed to incorporate the hallmarks of the Liverpool Curriculum Framework, in the following ways: 

Research-connected teaching: As part of the module students will have programme specific content designed and delivered by research-active/ connected scientists to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research and best evidence. Assessment submissions from learners should be evidence-based by their exploration of primary literature, and suitably referenced.  

Inclusivity and accessibility: Resource templates use accessible fonts and colour schemes. Content is uploaded to the VLE in advance, in a format compatible with assistive technologies and checked proactively with Ally. Format adjustments are also available on request in accordance with specific learning disabilities and support plans. Lectures are recorded and available on the VLE. 

Active learning: Structured participation will be interactive, using quizzes (e.g. PollEverywhere, Mentimeter, Kahoot) and collaborative, interactive tools (e.g. Padlet, Miro). Students will work together in groups to address an authentic challenge as part of the module. Formative exercises will provide students with regular feedback on their learning. 

Authentic assessment: The teaching and learning in this module, and the assessment strategy will foster skills desirable in many sectors of employment and those of lifelong learning. There are four assessments. Students will learn to communicate to difference audiences a key skill for scientists. One assessment, an essay which will encourage students to search literature and think critically whilst there is a written science communication where students will need to communicate using lay, non-technical language. In another assessment, students will work in groups to identify a solution to an authentic problem facing the life sciences sector. This will require problem-solving, critical thinking, project planning etc. There is also a portfolio where students will reflect on their skills development and academic feedback.

Confidence: This is developed continuously throughout the module. Tutorials are discursive and interactive, with learners contributing ideas and analysis to ongoing discussion. This builds confidence by creating a ‘safe space’ for sharing of ideas and expertise.  

Digital fluency: Digital fluency is encouraged through a combination of methods. The VLE is used for formative and summative assessment. Assessment activity also requires students to develop competency with digital technology. As part of one assessment, students will develop a group digital pitch showcasing a solution to a problem facing the life sciences sector.

Global citizenship: Students will study areas from their programme of interest at a Global Scale. Examples may include organisms, their development, their varied physiology, and immunity, infection, and therapeutics at a global scale. Our curriculum embeds values of inclusivity, equality and sustainability. In learning materials, we prioritise representation of diverse imagery and use scientific cases which reflect issues affecting marginalised communities.  

In exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
There are four assessments :
Assessment 1 - 1000 word essay (25%)
Assessment 2 - Individual Written report (500 words) and Group Digital Pitch with marks distributed according to peer assessed contribution (30%)
Assesement 3 - 750 word critique of a piece of lay science communication which has been generated by generative artificial intelligence (GAI) (25%)
Assessment 4 - Portfolio consisting of number of small tasks. (20%) This will include a skills audit, reflection on module tasks such as a cv and video interview and opportunity to reflect on academic feedback and the development of skills.

The assessment strategy has been guided by the Liverpool Curriculum Framework attributes and hallmarks, particularly with respect to confidence, active learning, digital fluency, and authentic assessment. Individual and group feedback on authentic-assessments and self-reflections aim to support the development of study and employability skills, such as resilience and ability to recognise, and act upon, constructive feedback. A key component of the assessment is therefore the production of a skills/self-reflection portfolio. In addition to the portfolio, the three other assessments are designed to be authentic and will require students to combine all the skills they have developed over the course of the module.

Reassessment will use the same format but the topic or data will differ. Mark will be capped at 40%. This will take place in the normal reassessment window. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

Notes
New module as part of programme revalidation. Due to commence September 2024, starting with year 1.

Overview

Overview
This 15-credit module will continue to develop students' communication and writing skills. In addition students will develop research, problem-solving and employability skills. This module will be built around fortnightly small-group tutorials with Academic Advisors with a weekly lecture to introduce the different themes. Students will complete four assessments which include an essay, a written critique of lay science communication, an individual report and group digital pitch, and a portfolio. As this module is taken by students on all programmes, to allow students to explore their interests different essay titles, journal papers and discussion topics relevant to students programme area of interest will be offered.
Educational Aims
This module aims to:

● To further develop students’ problem solving and critical thinking skills;

● To further develop students’ ability to reflect on their progress and use feedback to identify opportunities for personal development;

● To further develop students' employability, career thinking and engagement with industry;

● To further develop students written and communication skills;

● To help students continue to develop a professional relationship with peers and academics.
Marketing Module Synopsis
This module will continue to develop students’ transferable skills and will build on the year 1 skills module. It will focus on improving the students’ written, communication, and employability skills. As this module is taken by students on all programmes, to allow students to explore their interests different essay titles, journal papers and discussion topics relevant to students programme area of interest will be offered. Students will complete four assessments which include an essay, a written critique of lay science communication, an individual report and group digital pitch, and a portfolio. The module is based on fortnightly small-group tutorials with an Academic Advisor. Each tutorial will have a topic that relates to a small task which students need to complete either before or after the tutorial. The topics will be introduced within plenary lectures. In addition to the plenary lectures relating to skills development and employability, students will also receive lectures and seminars relating to programme specific content. These lectures will form the basis for discussions in programme specific tutorials
Outline Syllabus
Lecture and tutorial themes:

Publishing and citing research
● The peer review process
● Primary research articles

Communicating with different audiences
● Principles and forms of communication
● Effective communication
● Audiences
● Relevance for science/ employability

Giving presentations and digital pitches
● Designing and delivering a presentation or digital pitch
● Presentation tools

Critical thinking
● Why is critical thinking important?

Self-reflection
● Why is self-reflection important?
● Relevance to employability

Teamwork
● Why work in teams?
● How to be a successful team member
● Inclusive working and valuing perspectives

Employability
● Developing your CV
● Developing video interview skills
● How to target your application

Sustainability
● Responsible and sustainable innovation in Biosciences

Research Ethics
● Ethics of experimentation on animals and humans
● University's ethical policies and procedures
● Ethical approval process


These underpinning and additional skills will be recorded and assessed within the reflective portfolio. Submission of summative assessments will be through Canvas. Students will be expected to maintain their portfolio, prepare for small group tutorials and to carry out independent research to develop the content of their summative assessments.
Teaching and Learning Methods
The module is based on fortnightly small-group tutorials with an Academic Advisor. Each tutorial will have a topic that relates to a small task which students need to complete either before or after the tutorial. The topics will be introduced within plenary lectures. In addition to the plenary lectures relating to skills development and employability, students will also receive lectures and seminars relating to programme specific content. These lectures will form the basis for discussions in programme specific tutorials. Tutorial topics will include e.g. research skills, writing skills, and career development. In the tutorial, anonymous examples of appropriate and inappropriate resources will be evaluated and discussed. The portfolio will contain a number of small tasks which include a skills audit, reflection on module tasks such as cv and video interviews and opportunity to reflect on academic feedback and the development of skills. The tasks will be marked using simple rubrics. In addition to the portfolio there are three marked written assessments, one in Semester 1 and two in Semester 2.

Teaching method 1 – Lectures
Lectures will introduce the topic and skills which will be developed in each of the study cycles. Lectures will be related to the theme/ topic areas outlined in the Outline Syllabus section.
Attendance recorded: Yes

Teaching method 2 – Seminars
Seminars will supplement the material provided in the lectures and have more of a programme specific content focus. These seminars will form the basis for discussions in the programme specific tutorials.
Attendance recorded: Yes

Teaching method 3 – Tutorials
Students will have fortnightly small group tutorials with an Academic Advisor. Each tutorial will have a topic that relates to a small task which students need to complete either before or after the tutorial
Attendance recorded: Yes

The nature and implementation of this method is specifically designed to incorporate the hallmarks of the Liverpool Curriculum Framework, in the following ways: 

Research-connected teaching: As part of the module students will have programme specific content designed and delivered by research-active/ connected scientists to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research and best evidence. Assessment submissions from learners should be evidence-based by their exploration of primary literature, and suitably referenced.  

Inclusivity and accessibility: Resource templates use accessible fonts and colour schemes. Content is uploaded to the VLE in advance, in a format compatible with assistive technologies and checked proactively with Ally. Format adjustments are also available on request in accordance with specific learning disabilities and support plans. Lectures are recorded and available on the VLE. 

Active learning: Structured participation will be interactive, using quizzes (e.g. PollEverywhere, Mentimeter, Kahoot) and collaborative, interactive tools (e.g. Padlet, Miro). Students will work together in groups to address an authentic challenge as part of the module. Formative exercises will provide students with regular feedback on their learning. 

Authentic assessment: The teaching and learning in this module, and the assessment strategy will foster skills desirable in many sectors of employment and those of lifelong learning. There are four assessments. Students will learn to communicate to difference audiences a key skill for scientists. One assessment, an essay which will encourage students to search literature and think critically whilst there is a written science communication where students will need to communicate using lay, non-technical language. In another assessment, students will work in groups to identify a solution to an authentic problem facing the life sciences sector. This will require problem-solving, critical thinking, project planning etc. There is also a portfolio where students will reflect on their skills development and academic feedback.

Confidence: This is developed continuously throughout the module. Tutorials are discursive and interactive, with learners contributing ideas and analysis to ongoing discussion. This builds confidence by creating a ‘safe space’ for sharing of ideas and expertise.  

Digital fluency: Digital fluency is encouraged through a combination of methods. The VLE is used for formative and summative assessment. Assessment activity also requires students to develop competency with digital technology. As part of one assessment, students will develop a group digital pitch showcasing a solution to a problem facing the life sciences sector.

Global citizenship: Students will study areas from their programme of interest at a Global Scale. Examples may include organisms, their development, their varied physiology, and immunity, infection, and therapeutics at a global scale. Our curriculum embeds values of inclusivity, equality and sustainability. In learning materials, we prioritise representation of diverse imagery and use scientific cases which reflect issues affecting marginalised communities.  

In exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
There are four assessments :
Assessment 1 - 1000 word essay (25%)
Assessment 2 - Individual Written report (500 words) and Group Digital Pitch with marks distributed according to peer assessed contribution (30%)
Assesement 3 - 750 word critique of a piece of lay science communication which has been generated by generative artificial intelligence (GAI) (25%)
Assessment 4 - Portfolio consisting of number of small tasks. (20%) This will include a skills audit, reflection on module tasks such as a cv and video interview and opportunity to reflect on academic feedback and the development of skills.

The assessment strategy has been guided by the Liverpool Curriculum Framework attributes and hallmarks, particularly with respect to confidence, active learning, digital fluency, and authentic assessment. Individual and group feedback on authentic-assessments and self-reflections aim to support the development of study and employability skills, such as resilience and ability to recognise, and act upon, constructive feedback. A key component of the assessment is therefore the production of a skills/self-reflection portfolio. In addition to the portfolio, the three other assessments are designed to be authentic and will require students to combine all the skills they have developed over the course of the module.

Reassessment will use the same format but the topic or data will differ. Mark will be capped at 40%. This will take place in the normal reassessment window. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

Notes
New module as part of programme revalidation. Due to commence September 2024, starting with year 1.

Overview

Overview
This 15-credit module will continue to develop students' communication and writing skills. In addition students will develop research, problem-solving and employability skills. This module will be built around fortnightly small-group tutorials with Academic Advisors with a weekly lecture to introduce the different themes. Students will complete four assessments which include an essay, a written critique of lay science communication, an individual report and group digital pitch, and a portfolio. As this module is taken by students on all programmes, to allow students to explore their interests different essay titles, journal papers and discussion topics relevant to students programme area of interest will be offered.
Educational Aims
This module aims to:

● To further develop students’ problem solving and critical thinking skills;

● To further develop students’ ability to reflect on their progress and use feedback to identify opportunities for personal development;

● To further develop students' employability, career thinking and engagement with industry;

● To further develop students written and communication skills;

● To help students continue to develop a professional relationship with peers and academics.
Marketing Module Synopsis
This module will continue to develop students’ transferable skills and will build on the year 1 skills module. It will focus on improving the students’ written, communication, and employability skills. As this module is taken by students on all programmes, to allow students to explore their interests different essay titles, journal papers and discussion topics relevant to students programme area of interest will be offered. Students will complete four assessments which include an essay, a written critique of lay science communication, an individual report and group digital pitch, and a portfolio. The module is based on fortnightly small-group tutorials with an Academic Advisor. Each tutorial will have a topic that relates to a small task which students need to complete either before or after the tutorial. The topics will be introduced within plenary lectures. In addition to the plenary lectures relating to skills development and employability, students will also receive lectures and seminars relating to programme specific content. These lectures will form the basis for discussions in programme specific tutorials
Outline Syllabus
Lecture and tutorial themes:

Publishing and citing research
● The peer review process
● Primary research articles

Communicating with different audiences
● Principles and forms of communication
● Effective communication
● Audiences
● Relevance for science/ employability

Giving presentations and digital pitches
● Designing and delivering a presentation or digital pitch
● Presentation tools

Critical thinking
● Why is critical thinking important?

Self-reflection
● Why is self-reflection important?
● Relevance to employability

Teamwork
● Why work in teams?
● How to be a successful team member
● Inclusive working and valuing perspectives

Employability
● Developing your CV
● Developing video interview skills
● How to target your application

Sustainability
● Responsible and sustainable innovation in Biosciences

Research Ethics
● Ethics of experimentation on animals and humans
● University's ethical policies and procedures
● Ethical approval process


These underpinning and additional skills will be recorded and assessed within the reflective portfolio. Submission of summative assessments will be through Canvas. Students will be expected to maintain their portfolio, prepare for small group tutorials and to carry out independent research to develop the content of their summative assessments.
Teaching and Learning Methods
The module is based on fortnightly small-group tutorials with an Academic Advisor. Each tutorial will have a topic that relates to a small task which students need to complete either before or after the tutorial. The topics will be introduced within plenary lectures. In addition to the plenary lectures relating to skills development and employability, students will also receive lectures and seminars relating to programme specific content. These lectures will form the basis for discussions in programme specific tutorials. Tutorial topics will include e.g. research skills, writing skills, and career development. In the tutorial, anonymous examples of appropriate and inappropriate resources will be evaluated and discussed. The portfolio will contain a number of small tasks which include a skills audit, reflection on module tasks such as cv and video interviews and opportunity to reflect on academic feedback and the development of skills. The tasks will be marked using simple rubrics. In addition to the portfolio there are three marked written assessments, one in Semester 1 and two in Semester 2.

Teaching method 1 – Lectures
Lectures will introduce the topic and skills which will be developed in each of the study cycles. Lectures will be related to the theme/ topic areas outlined in the Outline Syllabus section.
Attendance recorded: Yes

Teaching method 2 – Seminars
Seminars will supplement the material provided in the lectures and have more of a programme specific content focus. These seminars will form the basis for discussions in the programme specific tutorials.
Attendance recorded: Yes

Teaching method 3 – Tutorials
Students will have fortnightly small group tutorials with an Academic Advisor. Each tutorial will have a topic that relates to a small task which students need to complete either before or after the tutorial
Attendance recorded: Yes

The nature and implementation of this method is specifically designed to incorporate the hallmarks of the Liverpool Curriculum Framework, in the following ways: 

Research-connected teaching: As part of the module students will have programme specific content designed and delivered by research-active/ connected scientists to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research and best evidence. Assessment submissions from learners should be evidence-based by their exploration of primary literature, and suitably referenced.  

Inclusivity and accessibility: Resource templates use accessible fonts and colour schemes. Content is uploaded to the VLE in advance, in a format compatible with assistive technologies and checked proactively with Ally. Format adjustments are also available on request in accordance with specific learning disabilities and support plans. Lectures are recorded and available on the VLE. 

Active learning: Structured participation will be interactive, using quizzes (e.g. PollEverywhere, Mentimeter, Kahoot) and collaborative, interactive tools (e.g. Padlet, Miro). Students will work together in groups to address an authentic challenge as part of the module. Formative exercises will provide students with regular feedback on their learning. 

Authentic assessment: The teaching and learning in this module, and the assessment strategy will foster skills desirable in many sectors of employment and those of lifelong learning. There are four assessments. Students will learn to communicate to difference audiences a key skill for scientists. One assessment, an essay which will encourage students to search literature and think critically whilst there is a written science communication where students will need to communicate using lay, non-technical language. In another assessment, students will work in groups to identify a solution to an authentic problem facing the life sciences sector. This will require problem-solving, critical thinking, project planning etc. There is also a portfolio where students will reflect on their skills development and academic feedback.

Confidence: This is developed continuously throughout the module. Tutorials are discursive and interactive, with learners contributing ideas and analysis to ongoing discussion. This builds confidence by creating a ‘safe space’ for sharing of ideas and expertise.  

Digital fluency: Digital fluency is encouraged through a combination of methods. The VLE is used for formative and summative assessment. Assessment activity also requires students to develop competency with digital technology. As part of one assessment, students will develop a group digital pitch showcasing a solution to a problem facing the life sciences sector.

Global citizenship: Students will study areas from their programme of interest at a Global Scale. Examples may include organisms, their development, their varied physiology, and immunity, infection, and therapeutics at a global scale. Our curriculum embeds values of inclusivity, equality and sustainability. In learning materials, we prioritise representation of diverse imagery and use scientific cases which reflect issues affecting marginalised communities.  

In exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
There are four assessments :
Assessment 1 - 1000 word essay (25%)
Assessment 2 - Individual Written report (500 words) and Group Digital Pitch with marks distributed according to peer assessed contribution (30%)
Assesement 3 - 750 word critique of a piece of lay science communication which has been generated by generative artificial intelligence (GAI) (25%)
Assessment 4 - Portfolio consisting of number of small tasks. (20%) This will include a skills audit, reflection on module tasks such as a cv and video interview and opportunity to reflect on academic feedback and the development of skills.

The assessment strategy has been guided by the Liverpool Curriculum Framework attributes and hallmarks, particularly with respect to confidence, active learning, digital fluency, and authentic assessment. Individual and group feedback on authentic-assessments and self-reflections aim to support the development of study and employability skills, such as resilience and ability to recognise, and act upon, constructive feedback. A key component of the assessment is therefore the production of a skills/self-reflection portfolio. In addition to the portfolio, the three other assessments are designed to be authentic and will require students to combine all the skills they have developed over the course of the module.

Reassessment will use the same format but the topic or data will differ. Mark will be capped at 40%. This will take place in the normal reassessment window. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

Deliveries

 LocationPeriod 
 
University of Liverpool Main Campus
Whole Session


Outcomes

BIOS205
Notes
New module as part of programme revalidation. Due to commence September 2024, starting with year 1.

Overview

Overview
This 15-credit module will continue to develop students' communication and writing skills. In addition students will develop research, problem-solving and employability skills. This module will be built around fortnightly small-group tutorials with Academic Advisors with a weekly lecture to introduce the different themes. Students will complete four assessments which include an essay, a written critique of lay science communication, an individual report and group digital pitch, and a portfolio. As this module is taken by students on all programmes, to allow students to explore their interests different essay titles, journal papers and discussion topics relevant to students programme area of interest will be offered.
Educational Aims
This module aims to:

● To further develop students’ problem solving and critical thinking skills;

● To further develop students’ ability to reflect on their progress and use feedback to identify opportunities for personal development;

● To further develop students' employability, career thinking and engagement with industry;

● To further develop students written and communication skills;

● To help students continue to develop a professional relationship with peers and academics.
Marketing Module Synopsis
This module will continue to develop students’ transferable skills and will build on the year 1 skills module. It will focus on improving the students’ written, communication, and employability skills. As this module is taken by students on all programmes, to allow students to explore their interests different essay titles, journal papers and discussion topics relevant to students programme area of interest will be offered. Students will complete four assessments which include an essay, a written critique of lay science communication, an individual report and group digital pitch, and a portfolio. The module is based on fortnightly small-group tutorials with an Academic Advisor. Each tutorial will have a topic that relates to a small task which students need to complete either before or after the tutorial. The topics will be introduced within plenary lectures. In addition to the plenary lectures relating to skills development and employability, students will also receive lectures and seminars relating to programme specific content. These lectures will form the basis for discussions in programme specific tutorials
Outline Syllabus
Lecture and tutorial themes:

Publishing and citing research
● The peer review process
● Primary research articles

Communicating with different audiences
● Principles and forms of communication
● Effective communication
● Audiences
● Relevance for science/ employability

Giving presentations and digital pitches
● Designing and delivering a presentation or digital pitch
● Presentation tools

Critical thinking
● Why is critical thinking important?

Self-reflection
● Why is self-reflection important?
● Relevance to employability

Teamwork
● Why work in teams?
● How to be a successful team member
● Inclusive working and valuing perspectives

Employability
● Developing your CV
● Developing video interview skills
● How to target your application

Sustainability
● Responsible and sustainable innovation in Biosciences

Research Ethics
● Ethics of experimentation on animals and humans
● University's ethical policies and procedures
● Ethical approval process


These underpinning and additional skills will be recorded and assessed within the reflective portfolio. Submission of summative assessments will be through Canvas. Students will be expected to maintain their portfolio, prepare for small group tutorials and to carry out independent research to develop the content of their summative assessments.
Teaching and Learning Methods
The module is based on fortnightly small-group tutorials with an Academic Advisor. Each tutorial will have a topic that relates to a small task which students need to complete either before or after the tutorial. The topics will be introduced within plenary lectures. In addition to the plenary lectures relating to skills development and employability, students will also receive lectures and seminars relating to programme specific content. These lectures will form the basis for discussions in programme specific tutorials. Tutorial topics will include e.g. research skills, writing skills, and career development. In the tutorial, anonymous examples of appropriate and inappropriate resources will be evaluated and discussed. The portfolio will contain a number of small tasks which include a skills audit, reflection on module tasks such as cv and video interviews and opportunity to reflect on academic feedback and the development of skills. The tasks will be marked using simple rubrics. In addition to the portfolio there are three marked written assessments, one in Semester 1 and two in Semester 2.

Teaching method 1 – Lectures
Lectures will introduce the topic and skills which will be developed in each of the study cycles. Lectures will be related to the theme/ topic areas outlined in the Outline Syllabus section.
Attendance recorded: Yes

Teaching method 2 – Seminars
Seminars will supplement the material provided in the lectures and have more of a programme specific content focus. These seminars will form the basis for discussions in the programme specific tutorials.
Attendance recorded: Yes

Teaching method 3 – Tutorials
Students will have fortnightly small group tutorials with an Academic Advisor. Each tutorial will have a topic that relates to a small task which students need to complete either before or after the tutorial
Attendance recorded: Yes

The nature and implementation of this method is specifically designed to incorporate the hallmarks of the Liverpool Curriculum Framework, in the following ways: 

Research-connected teaching: As part of the module students will have programme specific content designed and delivered by research-active/ connected scientists to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research and best evidence. Assessment submissions from learners should be evidence-based by their exploration of primary literature, and suitably referenced.  

Inclusivity and accessibility: Resource templates use accessible fonts and colour schemes. Content is uploaded to the VLE in advance, in a format compatible with assistive technologies and checked proactively with Ally. Format adjustments are also available on request in accordance with specific learning disabilities and support plans. Lectures are recorded and available on the VLE. 

Active learning: Structured participation will be interactive, using quizzes (e.g. PollEverywhere, Mentimeter, Kahoot) and collaborative, interactive tools (e.g. Padlet, Miro). Students will work together in groups to address an authentic challenge as part of the module. Formative exercises will provide students with regular feedback on their learning. 

Authentic assessment: The teaching and learning in this module, and the assessment strategy will foster skills desirable in many sectors of employment and those of lifelong learning. There are four assessments. Students will learn to communicate to difference audiences a key skill for scientists. One assessment, an essay which will encourage students to search literature and think critically whilst there is a written science communication where students will need to communicate using lay, non-technical language. In another assessment, students will work in groups to identify a solution to an authentic problem facing the life sciences sector. This will require problem-solving, critical thinking, project planning etc. There is also a portfolio where students will reflect on their skills development and academic feedback.

Confidence: This is developed continuously throughout the module. Tutorials are discursive and interactive, with learners contributing ideas and analysis to ongoing discussion. This builds confidence by creating a ‘safe space’ for sharing of ideas and expertise.  

Digital fluency: Digital fluency is encouraged through a combination of methods. The VLE is used for formative and summative assessment. Assessment activity also requires students to develop competency with digital technology. As part of one assessment, students will develop a group digital pitch showcasing a solution to a problem facing the life sciences sector.

Global citizenship: Students will study areas from their programme of interest at a Global Scale. Examples may include organisms, their development, their varied physiology, and immunity, infection, and therapeutics at a global scale. Our curriculum embeds values of inclusivity, equality and sustainability. In learning materials, we prioritise representation of diverse imagery and use scientific cases which reflect issues affecting marginalised communities.  

In exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
There are four assessments :
Assessment 1 - 1000 word essay (25%)
Assessment 2 - Individual Written report (500 words) and Group Digital Pitch with marks distributed according to peer assessed contribution (30%)
Assesement 3 - 750 word critique of a piece of lay science communication which has been generated by generative artificial intelligence (GAI) (25%)
Assessment 4 - Portfolio consisting of number of small tasks. (20%) This will include a skills audit, reflection on module tasks such as a cv and video interview and opportunity to reflect on academic feedback and the development of skills.

The assessment strategy has been guided by the Liverpool Curriculum Framework attributes and hallmarks, particularly with respect to confidence, active learning, digital fluency, and authentic assessment. Individual and group feedback on authentic-assessments and self-reflections aim to support the development of study and employability skills, such as resilience and ability to recognise, and act upon, constructive feedback. A key component of the assessment is therefore the production of a skills/self-reflection portfolio. In addition to the portfolio, the three other assessments are designed to be authentic and will require students to combine all the skills they have developed over the course of the module.

Reassessment will use the same format but the topic or data will differ. Mark will be capped at 40%. This will take place in the normal reassessment window. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
